texts.shortText: Probably the most unique and remarkable of all regional worms. Lives permanently in a papery tube that is open at both ends and is either embedded in a crevice between rocks, or in soft substrata. The body is divided into several very distinct sections – the first 9 segments are flattened and have lateral appendages; there follows a ring–like structure with long terminal horns and then three segments that each bear large semicircular paddles. Behind this the posterior segments each have large, branched, white parapodia that serve as gills.
Body length typically about 80 mm, but can be much larger.

Global: Supposedly cosmopolitan, but recent molecular work suggests that several distinct regional species are in fact subsumed under this one name.

Local/Regional: Angola to about East London.

An extraordinary and unmistakable species with a remarkable method of filter-feeding. The wing-like appendages on segment 10 secrete a mucous net that is extended backwards into a bag by the pumping action of the three paddle-like appendages behind it. As water passes through this net fine organic particles are trapped by it. Sections of the mucous bag are then cut off and passed forwards to the mouth to be eaten!

Apart from this amazing feeding mechanism, Chaetopterus worms also frequently host commensal species within their tubes. On a global basis these include a number of scaleworm species, many species of crab and even a nudibranch that is reputed to feed on the mucous net. This species is also well known for exhibiting strong bioluminescence. The function of this is unknown, since the worms do not posses light-detecting organs and spend their entire lives buried inside their tubes!
Filter feeder, collecting fine particulate material from the water pumped though the tube by filtering it though a mucous net.

Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae. The larvae are renowned for the long periods they spend in the plankton (up to a year in some genera in the family).

Unlikely to be confused with any other species, although the single name currently applied to specimens from around the globe is almost certainly incorrect and several distinct regional species probably exist.

Other much smaller (<20 mm), more slender members of this family also occur commonly along the subtropical east coast, where they live in groups of small sandy tubes, often among zoanthids.
